I don't feel bad about making private meth=
ods package scope in order  
to test them.  Testing trumps encapsulation.

=
However, if I can cover (as measured with a coverage tool) the  
private me=
thods by calling public methods, I will do that rather than  
test the priv=
ate methods explicitly.

In most cases covering the private methods by call=
ing the public  
methods is feasible since the population of functions that=
 call the  
private methods *is* the public, protected, and package scope m=
ethods  
of that class.  If any line within a private method is not execute=
d  
by the unit tests of the other methods, then either you need to add a  =

new test case or the line in the private method is not really needed.
